case_name: V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.

facts.text: High Court passed an order dated 9th March, 2007 setting aside the State Administrative Tribunal order in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent it held V. Jagannadha Rao judgment prospective.

anchor.surface_text: an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: High Court dismissed review petition on 3rd November, 2010.

anchor.surface_text: An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

facts.text: Supreme Court in V. Jagannadha Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh, 2001 10 SCC 401 held Special Rules framed by Governor under Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category violative of Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

facts.text: Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D to provide equitable opportunities in public employment.

anchor.surface_text: Answering the question in the affirmative this Court held that the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities and facilities to the people belonging to different parts of the State in the matter of public employment, education etc.

facts.text: GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 made UDCs of Labour Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspector of Labour.

anchor.surface_text: The question had arisen on account of a challenge mounted by the Ministerial employees of the Labour Department against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made employees of Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

anchor.surface_text: against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned Rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order.

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of Tribunal before whom the challenge came up for companysideration declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be companysidered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

facts.text: G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 provided Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices eligible for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training  Ser. IV  Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department companystitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved by G.O.Ms as Assistant Labour Officer is zonal post.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal. Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel.

facts.text: Tribunal partly allowed petitions by order dated 7th March, 2003 striking down G.O.M. No.14 and amendment prospectively.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were partly allowed by the Tribunal in terms of its order dated 7th March, 2003 and G.O.M. No.14, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 struck down as unconstitutional to the extent the same provided a channel for Senior Assistant and Senior Stenographer in Andhra Pradesh Ministerial Service working in the Head Offices of Labour Department and those in Factories and Boiler Departments besides those in the Subordinate Offices in the said Departments for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal directed that striking down prospective and no disturbance to actions till 7th November, 2001.

anchor.surface_text: Having said that the Tribunal directed that the striking down of the impugned O.Ms. would only be prospective and that any action taken in companypliance with the said Rules till 7th November, 2001 shall number be disturbed number any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra  reverted.

facts.text: Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal's prospective overruling.

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved employees, who had approached the Tribunal having succeeded but only in part, filed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 whereby they challenged the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made on the basis of the impugned G.O.Ms.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 filed against Tribunal judgment striking down GOMs.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 was also filed against the very same judgment by some of the employees who felt aggrieved by the view taken by the Tribunal that the impugned G.O.Ms. were in violation of the Presidential Order hence unconstitutional.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed WP 6163 and 6068/2004, dismissed WP 16890/2006.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court.

facts.text: Appellants are employees not arrayed as parties to the writ petition before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were number arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court.

facts.text: Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010 filed by appellants, dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, companytending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

facts.text: OA No.6334 of 1997 filed before State Administrative Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997

facts.text: In VJR case, petitions filed in 1987, Tribunal order dated 17th April, 1995.

anchor.surface_text: In Jagannadha Raos case  supra , the petitions were filed in the year 1987. The State Administrative Tribunal had declared the rule providing for inter-department transfer by promotion to be bad by its order dated 17th April, 1995.

facts.text: Present OAs filed before Tribunal in 1997, Tribunal order dated 27th March, 2003.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in the present case were filed before the State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997. The Tribunal had on the authority of the judgment aforementioned struck down the rules providing for ex-cadre zone promotions by its order dated 27th March, 2003, but saved the promotions already made.

facts.text: Promotions made before 7th November, 2001 continued for nearly ten years.

anchor.surface_text: Promotions made before the pronouncement of the order in Jagannadha Raos case  supra  i.e. before 7th November, 2001 have, thus, companytinued for nearly ten years till the review petition filed by the petitioners was dismissed and the matter brought up before this Court.

issues.text: whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category were violative of para 5(2) of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D

anchor.surface_text: a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950. Answering the question in the affirmative this Court held that the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities

issues.text: whether the term 'transfer' in para 5(2) of the Presidential Order includes promotion

anchor.surface_text: No provision or word in a statute has to be read in isolation. In fact, the statute has to be read as a whole. A statute is an edict of the legislature. It cannot be said that without any purpose the distinction was made in para 5 1  between transfer and promotion and such distinction was not intended to be operative in para 5 2 . The intention of the legislature is primarily to be gathered from the language used, which means that attention should be paid as to what has been said as also to what has not been said.

issues.text: whether rules under Article 309 are subject to and overridden by Presidential Order under Article 371-D(10)

anchor.surface_text: Overruling the decisions rendered by this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr. v. V. Sadanandam and Ors. 1989 Supp.  1  SCC 574, and in Govt. Of A.P. and Anr. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao  Dead  by Lrs. And Ors.  2000  4 SCC 262, this Court held that in terms of Article 371-D  10  of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of the Constitution or in any law for the time being in force.

issues.text: whether inclusion of employees from outside the zone in the feeding channel for appointment by transfer to zonal post of Assistant Labour Officer violates paras 3(3) and 5(1) of the Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel. Inclusion of other categories from outside the zone in the feeding channel for purposes of promotion or appointment by transfer was offensive to paras 3 3  and 5 1  of the Andhra Pradesh Public Employment  Organisation of Local Cards and Regulation of Direct Recruitment  Order, 1975 referred to hereinabove as the Presidential Order against the employees.

issues.text: whether the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Courts including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution. The net effect of the view taken by the High Court, therefore, is that not only are the impugned G.O.M. held to be unconstitutional, but any action taken pursuant thereto is also declared to be unconstitutional.

issues.text: whether the Supreme Court should invoke the doctrine of prospective overruling to save past promotions made under the invalid GOMs

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no option but to examine the question of invoking the doctrine of prospective overruling on the merits of the case having regard to the facts and circumstances in which the question arises. While doing so we must at the threshold point out that the respondents are not correct in suggesting as though the petitioners had taken any deliberate or calculated risk by opting for promotion outside their cadres.

issues.text: whether failure to implead affected employees as parties vitiates the judgment striking down the GOMs

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

arguments.court_reasoning: Promotions ordered by State, not snatched; no element of risk at time made

arguments.claim: Supreme Court should invoke prospective overruling to save past promotions as held long time, reversion harsh, law in flux till VJR judgment

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent ... argued ... nothing prevented this Court from doing so having regard to the fact that those promoted under the impugned rules had held their respective positions for a considerable length of time making reversion to their parent zone cadre not only administratively difficult but unreasonably harsh and unfair.

arguments.court_reasoning: Similar facts: long-held positions, cascading effect, non-impleadment, law flux

arguments.claim: Transfer does not include promotion; distinction in paras 5(1) and 5(2) of Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: No provision or word in a statute has to be read in isolation. ... It cannot be said that without any purpose the distinction was made in para 5(1) between transfer and promotion and such distinction was not intended to be operative in para 5(2).

arguments.claim: Rules under Article 309 subject to Presidential Order under Article 371D(10)

anchor.surface_text: Overruling the decisions ... this Court held that in terms of Article 371-D(10) of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of the Constitution or in any law for the time being in force.

arguments.claim: Doctrine of prospective overruling applicable by Supreme Court under Article 142 to save past promotions; law in flux, non-impleadment, long-held positions
Reversion after long promotions unjust, cascading effect on juniors

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position reverting these officers at this distant point of time, to the posts of Senior Stenographers in their parent cadre does not appear to us to be either just, fair or equitable especially when upon reversion the State does not propose to promote them to the higher positions within their zone cadre

arguments.claim: VJR judgment not impediment as different GOMs and did not address prospective overruling

holdings.text: The doctrine of prospective overruling was available only to the Supreme Court and not to High Courts or Tribunals, but it is unnecessary to decide whether High Courts can invoke it since the Supreme Court can do so.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide for lower courts as Supreme Court possesses power under Article 142 to invoke it for complete justice regardless.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court invokes the doctrine of prospective overruling to save promotions made under the impugned G.O.Ms. prior to 7th November 2001 and directs that such actions shall not be disturbed.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotions held for long period (nearly 10 years), ordered by State not voluntary risk by employees, further promotions made, reversion unjust with cascading effect on juniors, affected parties not impleaded, law in flux till VJR judgment.

holdings.text: The judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao does not preclude application of prospective overruling as it addressed different rules and did not consider the issue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: VJR concerned different GOMs (72 and 117) and did not examine prospective overruling; basic question similar but facts distinguish.

holdings.text: Employees promoted under impugned rules did not take deliberate or calculated risk as promotions were ordered by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: While doing so we must at the threshold point out that the respondents are not correct in suggesting as though the petitioners had taken any deliberate or calculated risk by opting for promotion outside their cadres.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotions initiated and ordered by State authorities; no pending legal controversy or element of risk at the time of promotion.

holdings.text: Rules framed under proviso to Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category across local cadres/zones are violative of Presidential Order under Article 371-D including paras 3, 5(1) and 5(2).

anchor.surface_text: Overruling the decisions rendered by this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr. v. V. Sadanandam and Ors. 1989 Supp. 1 SCC 574, and in Govt. Of A.P. and Anr. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao Dead by Lrs. And Ors. 2000 4 SCC 262, this Court held that in terms of Article 371-D 10 of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presidential Order prevails per Art 371D(10); 'transfer' in para 5(2) excludes promotion per harmonious construction with para 5(1); local cadre unit for promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in support was placed upon the decision of this Court in Managing Director, ECIL Hyderabad v. B. Karunakar  1993  4 SCC 727.

precedents.case_name: Managing Director, ECIL v. B. Karunakar
precedents.cited_proposition: Prospective overruling when law in state of flux

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

outcome.relief_summary: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked to save past promotions made under impugned G.O.Ms prior to judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao case; High Court order set aside insofar as it held prospective overruling inapplicable
directions: Promotions made before 7th November 2001 not to be disturbed
No reversion of promoted employees to parent cadre
Balance equity between parties by prospective application

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

Overruling the decisions rendered by this Court in State of Andhra Pradesh and Anr. v. V. Sadanandam and Ors. 1989 Supp. 1 SCC 574, and in Govt. Of A.P. and Anr. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao Dead by Lrs. And Ors. 2000 4 SCC 262, this Court held that in terms of Article 371-D 10 of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.
